quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 6 Quiz 10
quiz.subtitle: 6.10: Grignard to Alcohols
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Synthesis of alcohols using Grignard reagents

questions.question: What is the general formula for a Grignard reagent?
questions.explanation: A Grignard reagent consists of an alkyl or aryl group ($R$) bonded to magnesium ($Mg$), which is also bonded to a halogen ($X$).

questions.question: In a Grignard reagent, the carbon atom bonded to the magnesium acts as a(n):
questions.explanation: Because magnesium is much less electronegative than carbon, the $C-Mg$ bond is highly polarized, giving the carbon a strong partial negative charge (carbanion character).

questions.question: The reaction of a Grignard reagent with methanal (formaldehyde) followed by acid hydrolysis produces:
questions.explanation: Methanal has only hydrogens attached to the carbonyl. Adding one $R$ group from the Grignard reagent results in an $R-CH_{2}OH$ structure.

questions.question: Which carbonyl compound must be used with a Grignard reagent to synthesize a secondary alcohol?
questions.explanation: Aldehydes like ethanal already have one $R$ group; adding a second $R$ group from the Grignard reagent creates a secondary alcohol.

questions.question: Reacting a Grignard reagent with a ketone produces:
questions.explanation: Ketones already have two $R$ groups. Adding a third from the Grignard reagent results in a tertiary alcohol.

questions.question: Why must Grignard reactions be carried out in anhydrous (water-free) conditions, such as dry ether?
options: Grignard reagents react violently with water to form alkanes.
Water acts as a catalyst and makes the reaction too fast.
Water prevents the Grignard reagent from dissolving.
The carbonyl group will evaporate in the presence of water.
questions.explanation: Grignard reagents are very strong bases; they will immediately abstract a proton from water to form an alkane ($R-H$), destroying the reagent.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the second step (acid workup) in a Grignard reaction?
options: To protonate the alkoxide intermediate to form the final alcohol.
To remove the magnesium metal from the flask.
To oxidize the alcohol into a ketone.
questions.explanation: The initial addition forms a magnesium alkoxide salt. Adding dilute acid ($H_{3}O^{+}$) provides the proton needed to create the neutral alcohol.

questions.question: Which of the following is produced when a Grignard reagent reacts with carbon dioxide ($CO_{2}$)?
questions.explanation: The Grignard reagent attacks the carbon in $CO_{2}$, and after acid workup, it forms a carboxylic acid ($R-COOH$).

questions.question: If you react methylmagnesium bromide ($CH_{3}MgBr$) with propanone, what is the final product?
questions.explanation: Propanone is a ketone. Adding a methyl group to the central carbon creates a 4-carbon tertiary alcohol.

questions.question: Which solvent is most commonly used to prepare and store Grignard reagents?
questions.explanation: Diethyl ether is an aprotic solvent that stabilizes the Grignard reagent by coordinating the lone pairs of the oxygen with the magnesium atom.

scoreMessages.90: Fantastic! You've mastered the complexity of Grignard synthesis.
scoreMessages.70: Great work. You have a solid understanding of C-C bond formation.
scoreMessages.50: Good job. Remember: Methanal → 1°, Aldehyde → 2°, Ketone → 3°.
scoreMessages.0: Review the nucleophilic nature of the Grignard reagent.
